div.sent: In a transparent medium light goes in a straight line with a definite velocity.
When it goes from a transparent medium to a less transparent one, a certain portion of light is absorbed and rest of it is reflected.
But what happens if light passes from a transparent medium to another transparent medium?
Does its velocity remain the same?
We shall discuss these issues in this chapter.
Take a glass and fill half of it with water.
Dip a portion of your pencil in it and incline it slightly.
How does the pencil look?
It looks bent.
We know that we see anything when light from the thing comes to our eyes.
Here light from the pencil under water comes from one transparent medium-water to another transparent medium-air and then comes to our eyes.
The pencil is seen bent; that means light rays must have been bent in course of its journey from water to air.
If it took the same straight path in water and air, the pencil would look straight too.
So it can be concluded that light rays in passing from one transparent medium (water) to another transparent medium (air) alter their directions.
Such changes in the directions of light are called refraction of light.
In a transparent medium light goes in a straight line.
So change of its direction takes place at the bordering line where the two media meet.
Let us do an experiment to know which way the direction of light rays should change, when it passes from one medium to another.
Take a rectangular glass slab and place it on a white paper on a table.
Draw its outline ABCD by a pencil (Fig. 12.1).
On one side of the slab place two pins p1 and p2 straight obliquely.
With a pencil mark the positions of the pins on papers.
Join OQ and draw perpendiculars NON1 and N2QN3 at the points O and Q respectively.
Here, p1p2 is a light ray coming from air medium that falls on glass medium at O which is called point of incidence.
This ray is called incident ray.
Incident ray makes the angle P1ON with the perpendicular NONThis angle is called incident angle.
OQ is the ray in the glass medium corresponding to the incident ray P1O.
Again it changes direction at the point Q and goes along Qp3p.
The path of the light ray is along p1p2 OQ p3p4.
This is the rule followed by light rays when refraction takes place.
What happens when light goes normally from one medium to another?
There will be no refraction or bending of light, as such both the angles of incidence and refraction are zero.
So, we see that refraction obeys some laws.
For light falling normally on the plain of separation refracted light does not change direction.
Why do light rays entering from one medium to another change direction?
The reason for this is that velocity of light is not the same in all media.
Light travels at 3,00,000 km/s in vacuum and is almost the same in air.
This velocity is the highest.
But in glass medium it travels at 1,80,000km/s.
Light has a peculiar characteristic.
Light takes the path which will take the least time to travel.
But if light takes ADB path then in water it goes DB distance.
Now, the length of CB is greater than the length DB.
In water medium velocity of light is less, so greater time is necessary if light follows ACB path.
Therefore light chooses the special path ADB for which time taken is least.
How much the light ray will bend depends upon velocity in the second medium greater is the bending.
The velocity of light is less in glass than in that of water.
So, when light enters from air to glass light bends more than when it enters from air to water.
Take some water in a cup and dip a stick obliquely in it.
The stick is seen bent when looked from above.
Light from a point in the dipped portion comes from water to air medium i.e. from denser to rarer medium.
Therefore, according to law of refraction it will go away from the normal (Fig. 12.3).

Therefore either the stick will appear to be bent at the point of separation of the air and water.
It will be seen a bit short too.
Place a coin say, a 25 paisa coin, in a cup.
Place your eyes along the edge of the cup in such a way that the coin just goes out of your sight.
In such a position of eye pour water in the cup. the coin will be visible.
Light rays from the coin dipped in water travels from water to air i.e. from denser to rarer medium.
So after refraction they go away from normal and form virtual image at Q.

For the same reason a tank full of water appears raised at the bottom when looked at straight from above.
It appears that the depth of the tank has been decreased.
Objects situated in water can not be located exactly.
Because the fish is not there, it only appears to be there.
In reality the fish is at a bit bellow the place you see.
Refraction of light through lenses is used to make many instruments like camera, projector, telescope, microscope etc.
Spectacles which are used for correcting vision work on refraction of light.

Now increase angle of incidence, refracted angle will increase too.
This particular angle of incidence is called critical angle.
What happens if the angle of incidence is increased more than the critical angle?
Then the angle of refraction must be greater than 90.
But this angle can not be greater than 90 for it is the angle in a single medium.
So the ray will not enter rarer medium any more, instead it comes back to the same medium like reflection obeying its laws.
This case of refraction is called total internal reflection.

This is known as total internal reflection.
This is called total internal reflection.
Why is the internal reflection called total reflection?
Because, in ordinary reflection a part of light is reflected, and a part is refracted.
But in total reflection all the total amount of light is reflected, no part is refracted.
Can you think of any other ifference between them?
Mirage is a natural example of total internal reflection.
The sand of the desert becomes very hot at day time by intense sun light.
The surrounding air layers also become hot and hence lighter.
The temperature above decreases.
So air layers are dense as we go above.
Light coming from a distant high tree passes from denser to rarer medium gradually.
Due to rapid change of temperature density of air layer changes too.
Light coming through air of changing density changes the direction.
It makes the traveler take this trembling and reverse image of tree as the reflection of a tree on water surface.
So the tired and thirsty traveler is compelled to believe that there must be some oasis near the image.
He goes there for water but does not get any.
This optical illusion is called mirage.
In intense sunshine a pitched road sometime may appears to be wet and shining.
This is due to the same optical illusion described as above.
